title: Hurt
text:
Statute (paraphrased): 'Hurt' means causing bodily pain, disease, or infirmity to any person.
Layman explanation: If someone causes you physical pain, makes you ill, or weakens your body, it can be 'hurt' under IPC.
Key points: Focus is on pain/illness/weakness; visible injury is not mandatory.

title: Voluntarily causing hurt
text:
Statute (paraphrased): A person 'voluntarily causes hurt' if they do an act with the intention of causing hurt, or with knowledge that it is likely to cause hurt, and hurt is caused.
Layman explanation: If you hurt someone on purpose—or you do something knowing it will likely hurt them—this applies.
Example: Punching someone to cause pain, or throwing something knowing it may hit and hurt.

title: Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Punishment for voluntarily causing hurt is imprisonment up to 1 year, or fine, or both.
Layman explanation: If you intentionally cause 'simple hurt' (not grievous), you can be punished up to 1 year or fined.
Key points: This is for simple hurt; grievous hurt is handled separately under IPC.

title: Wrongful restraint
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Wrongful restraint is voluntarily obstructing a person so as to prevent them from proceeding in any direction in which they have a right to proceed.
Layman explanation: If someone blocks your way and stops you from going where you have a right to go, it may be wrongful restraint.
Example: Blocking a public pathway/exit to stop someone from leaving.

title: Punishment for wrongful restraint
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Whoever wrongfully restrains any person may be punished with simple imprisonment up to 1 month, or fine up to ₹500, or both.
Layman explanation: Blocking someone’s movement unlawfully can lead to up to 1 month jail or fine.

title: Criminal force
text:
Statute (paraphrased): 'Criminal force' is using force on a person without consent, intending to commit an offence, or intending/knowing it is likely to cause injury, fear, or annoyance.
Layman explanation: Using physical force like pushing/grabbing/slapping without consent—especially to intimidate or harm—can be criminal force.
Example: Grabbing someone’s arm to stop them, or pushing them to frighten them.

title: Assault
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Assault is any gesture or preparation that causes a person to reasonably apprehend that criminal force is about to be used.
Layman explanation: Even if you don’t touch someone, threatening actions that make them fear you are about to hit them can be assault.
Example: Raising a hand to strike or moving aggressively as if to attack.

title: Punishment for assault or criminal force otherwise than on grave provocation
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Punishment for assault or criminal force otherwise than on grave and sudden provocation is imprisonment up to 3 months, or fine, or both.
Layman explanation: Minor assault/pushing/slapping without a serious provocation can lead to up to 3 months jail or fine.

title: Assault or criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Assault or criminal force against a woman with intent to outrage her modesty is punishable with imprisonment and fine (as prescribed by law).
Layman explanation: Unwanted physical acts against a woman done with sexual intent or to violate dignity are punished under IPC 354.
Key points: The intention/knowledge about outraging modesty is crucial.

title: Punishment for theft
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Theft is punishable with imprisonment up to 3 years, or fine, or both.
Layman explanation: If someone steals movable property (like phone, wallet, bike), IPC 379 provides the punishment.
Key points: Theft definition is in IPC 378; IPC 379 is the punishment section.

title: Dishonest misappropriation of property
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Dishonest misappropriation is when someone dishonestly converts another person’s movable property to their own use.
Layman explanation: If you find someone’s lost item and keep it (or sell/use it) dishonestly instead of returning it, it can fall here.
Example: Keeping a found phone/wallet knowing it belongs to someone else.

title: Punishment for criminal breach of trust
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Criminal breach of trust is punishable when property is entrusted and is dishonestly misused/converted or not returned as required.
Layman explanation: If someone is trusted with your money/property and they misuse it or refuse to return it dishonestly, IPC 406 may apply.
Example: Someone given funds for a purpose uses it for themselves.

title: Cheating
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Cheating involves deception and dishonest/fraudulent inducement causing someone to deliver property or do/omit something that causes harm.
Layman explanation: If a person tricks you with a lie so you give money/property or suffer loss, it can be cheating.
Example: False promise to sell something, taking payment, then disappearing.

title: Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property/valuable security is punishable with imprisonment up to 7 years and fine.
Layman explanation: Serious cheating where the victim is induced to hand over property/money due to deception can fall under IPC 420.
Example: Online fraud/scam that makes a person transfer money.

title: Punishment for criminal intimidation
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Criminal intimidation is punishable when a person threatens another with injury to person/property/reputation with intent to cause alarm or compel action/inaction.
Layman explanation: Threatening someone (life/property/reputation) to scare them or force them to do something can be IPC 506.
Example: Threatening messages demanding someone withdraw a complaint.

title: Definitions
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Defines key terms like 'information', 'public authority', and the forms of access (inspection, copies, electronic records).
Layman explanation: RTI law explains what counts as information and who must provide it.
Key points: Includes documents, emails, reports, records, and electronic data.

title: Right to information
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Every citizen has the right to information held by public authorities, subject to exemptions.
Layman explanation: Any Indian citizen can ask government/public bodies for information unless it is legally exempt.

title: Obligations of public authorities
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Public authorities must proactively publish key information (suo motu disclosure) so citizens need not always file RTI.
Layman explanation: Many details should already be publicly available on websites/notice boards without you filing RTI.

title: Designation of Public Information Officers
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Public authorities must appoint Public Information Officers (PIOs) to receive and process RTI requests.
Layman explanation: Every department must have an RTI officer responsible for handling RTI applications.

title: Request for obtaining information
text:
Statute (paraphrased): RTI requests can be made to the PIO/Assistant PIO; applicant need not give reasons for seeking information.
Layman explanation: You can apply in writing/online to the RTI officer and you don’t need to explain why you want the information.

title: Disposal of request
text:
Statute (paraphrased): The PIO must respond within prescribed time limits—typically 30 days; faster timelines apply for urgent life/liberty matters.
Layman explanation: RTI has deadlines. Normally you should get a reply within 30 days; urgent matters have shorter limits.

title: Exemption from disclosure of information
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Lists exemptions (e.g., security, investigation, privacy, etc.) where information may be denied; some disclosures may still occur if public interest outweighs harm.
Layman explanation: Not everything can be shared under RTI. Certain sensitive categories can be refused.

title: Grounds for rejection to access
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Information may be rejected if disclosure would infringe copyright (other than the State’s copyright).
Layman explanation: If the information is protected by someone else’s copyright, the request can be denied.

title: Appeal
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Provides the first appeal and second appeal mechanism if information is denied or not provided.
Layman explanation: If the RTI officer rejects/doesn’t reply, you can appeal—first within the department, then to the Information Commission.

title: Penalties
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Provides penalties against PIOs for delay, malafide denial, incorrect information, or destruction of information.
Layman explanation: RTI law can fine the responsible officer if they delay without valid reason or deny information wrongly.

title: Definitions
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Defines terms like consumer, goods/services, defect/deficiency, unfair trade practice, misleading advertisement, product liability, etc.
Layman explanation: This section explains who is a consumer and what problems (defect/deficiency/unfair practices) the law covers.
Key points: Includes e-commerce and misleading ads in the broader framework.

title: Complaints to authorities
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Provides the Act’s framework for complaints relating to consumer rights issues, including misleading advertisements/unfair trade practices (as structured in the Act).
Layman explanation: If you face misleading ads or unfair practices, the Act provides ways to raise complaints within the system created by the law.

title: Jurisdiction of District Commission
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Sets the District Commission’s jurisdiction (where you can file), including pecuniary/territorial aspects as per the Act and updated rules/notifications.
Layman explanation: This tells you when a consumer case can be filed in the District Consumer Commission.
Note: Value limits may be updated by rules/notifications—keep configurable.

title: Manner in which complaint shall be made
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Describes how a consumer complaint should be filed, including the manner/format and filing modes as per rules.
Layman explanation: Explains the practical method to file a complaint (including online/electronic filing where allowed).

title: Admission of complaint
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Describes admission/scrutiny of complaints by the District Commission.
Layman explanation: The Commission checks whether your complaint is in order and maintainable before proceeding.

title: Jurisdiction of State Commission
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Sets State Commission jurisdiction (original/appellate/revisional as per the Act).
Layman explanation: Higher-level consumer disputes and appeals can go to the State Commission depending on jurisdiction rules.

title: Jurisdiction of National Commission
text:
Statute (paraphrased): Sets National Commission jurisdiction for high-value matters and certain appeals.
Layman explanation: Very high-value or specific appeal cases can go to the National Commission (NCDRC).

title: Limitation period
text:
Statute (paraphrased): A consumer complaint should generally be filed within 2 years from the cause of action; delay may be condoned for sufficient cause.
Layman explanation: Usually you must file within 2 years. If late, you must explain the reason and seek condonation.
